screens.headline: Is 1.4% monthly return on cash good enough?
screens.text: Let's calculate the REAL returns on cash-secured puts, including the opportunity cost of cash sitting idle and the risk if you get assigned underwater. The math that separates smart CSP traders from bagholders.

screens.headline: The 4 Numbers That Matter for CSPs
screens.text: Every CSP trade has four key calculations: (1) ROI on cash reserved, (2) Annualized return, (3) Effective purchase price if assigned, (4) Breakeven price. Understanding these BEFORE selling lets you compare CSPs to other investments.

screens.headline: Calculation #1: Return on Cash Reserved
screens.description: How much are you earning on the cash sitting in your account?
teaching_points: Try $10 premium: Higher premium = better returns
Try 45 days: Longer duration = lower annualized rate
Compare to: CD rates (5%), dividend stocks (2-4%)

screens.headline: Calculation #2: Effective Purchase Price
screens.description: If you get assigned, what's your REAL cost per share?
screens.formula_display: Effective Cost = Strike Price - Premium Collected
teaching_points: Premium ALWAYS improves your cost basis

screens.headline: Calculation #3: Which Strike is Better?
screens.description: Compare aggressive vs conservative CSP strikes
teaching_points: ATM = highest premium but 50% chance of assignment
OTM = lower premium but less likely to get assigned
Pick based on: Do you WANT to own this stock?

screens.question: You have $40,000 cash. You can: (A) Sell $400 put for $6 premium, or (B) Put cash in 5% savings. Which is better for 30 days?
options: A - CSP returns 1.5% (18% annualized) vs 5% annual savings
B - Savings is guaranteed, CSP has assignment risk
Both are equal - 5% annual = 1.5% per 30 days
It depends on whether you want to own the stock
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! If you WANT the stock, CSP is better (higher return + you'd buy anyway). If you DON'T want the stock, savings is safer. CSPs aren't 'better' - they're different risk profiles. Match to your goals!
screens.explanation_wrong: This isn't a math question - it's a strategy question. CSP has better return IF you want the stock. Savings is better IF you don't want assignment risk. What are YOUR goals?

screens.question: Stock $200. Sell $190 put for $4 OR $180 put for $2. You're VERY BULLISH and don't want to own the stock. Which CSP?
options: Don't sell any puts - you're too bullish
screens.explanation_correct: Smart! You're bullish (expect stock to stay up) AND don't want assignment. So sell the $180 put - far enough OTM that assignment is unlikely, but still collects $200 premium for doing nothing. Lower return but matches your outlook!
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about your goals: You're bullish (stock won't drop) and DON'T want ownership. The $180 put is 10% OTM - much safer from assignment while still earning premium. Match your strike to your outlook!

cards.back: (Premium / Strike Price) √ó 100. Annualize by √ó (365/days). Target 1-3% monthly (12-36% annual).
Strike Price - Premium. This is your TRUE cost if assigned. Always lower than strike!
Want to own stock? ATM (high premium, high assignment chance). Don't want stock? OTM (low premium, low risk).
